Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the US Ignite 2017 Application Summit, the 4th in a series of annual Summits, to be held on June 27-28 in Austin, Texas. The project will help defray the costs of travel and conference participation for 150 participants. The Summit will enable researchers from the gigabit networking community to demonstrate their research results to diverse stakeholders including municipal officials, community leaders, and application developers interested in Smart & Connected Communities and Cities.

The project will also convene an integrated Principal Investigators meeting for NSF-funded research programs including US Ignite, and Smart & Connect Communities, advancing their joint research agenda. The project will enable Application Summit participants to share best practices and lesson learned with one-another and with community leaders and stakeholders. The US Ignite 2017 Application Summit will be co-located with the Smart Cities Connect Conference, ensuring diverse participation from communities across the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On June 26 to 28, 2017, US Ignite hosted the US Ignite Application Summit at the Austin Convention Center in Austin, Texas. The 2017 Application Summit showcased 31 advanced networking applications that benefit the general public. The Summit highlighted six demonstrations that showed

  • Uses for the Microsoft Hololens in various applications such as education, visualization of complex data sets and distance communication;
  • Networked virtual reality for virtual field trips of a solar plant which permitted live-streamed 3D teacher imagery allowing experts from a real energy center to guide and assess students remotely;
  • Technology on two consecutive vehicles using high-throughput wi-fi routers connected to Chattanooga’s gigabit fiber internet giving a trailing vehicle real-time augmented view of a traffic that in reality may be blocked by the vehicle in front of it;
  • A system where a robot can automatically identify and track surrounding objects and people, as a building block of collaborative wireless-networked augmented vision;
  • An "App" to the harness unused computing power and dedicate it to researchers working towards a cure for cancer; and
  • A smart modeling platform to help building professional better understand and improve upon performance, so stakeholders can visualize and optimize return on investment to their projects and the community.

The 2017 Application Summit highlighted these as "main stage" demonstrations and hosted an additional 25 demonstrations during an advanced application exposition. 

The Summit is an opportunity to convene developers, technologists, corporate labs and academic researchers with the organizations, municipalities, and government leaders who want to address challenges in education, healthcare, transportation, public safety, advanced manufacturing and clean energy.  Over 1,800 individuals participated in the 2017 US Ignite Application Summit and the collocated Smart Cities Connect Conference and Expo. Attendees represented a broad range of organizations: academia, research labs, corporations, non-profit entities, and municipal government.  More than 450 local, county and state government representatives and 250 participants from academia participated in the 2017 Application Summit.

Collaboration between and among Summit participants is an important goal.  To facilitate cross-sector connections and collaborations, 1,200 participants registered to use a conference networking/collaboration app and used the app to set-up more than 900 meetings during the Summit. By establishing relationships with researchers/developers and communities, US Ignite has begun to break the barriers between the technology and those who could use it to solve societal issues.

The 2017 Application Summit showcased 31 advanced networking applications that benefit the general public. The Summit highlighted six demonstrations that showed Uses for the Microsoft Hololens in various applications such as education, visualization of complex data sets and distance communication; Networked virtual reality for virtual field trips of a solar plant which permitted live-streamed 3D teacher imagery allowing experts from a real energy center to guide and assess students remotely; Technology on two consecutive vehicles using high-throughput wi-fi routers connected to Chattanooga?s gigabit fiber internet giving a trailing vehicle real-time augmented view of a traffic that in reality may be blocked by the vehicle in front of it; A system where a robot can automatically identify and track surrounding objects and people, as a building block of collaborative wireless-networked augmented vision; An "App" to the harness unused computing power and dedicate it to researchers working towards a cure for cancer; and A smart modeling platform to help building professional better understand and improve upon performance, so stakeholders can visualize and optimize return on investment to their projects and the community. The 2017 Application Summit highlighted these as "main stage" demonstrations and hosted an additional 25 demonstrations during an advanced application exposition. The Summit is an opportunity to convene developers, technologists, corporate labs and academic researchers with the organizations, municipalities, and government leaders who want to address challenges in education, healthcare, transportation, public safety, advanced manufacturing and clean energy. Over 1,800 individuals participated in the 2017 US Ignite Application Summit and the collocated Smart Cities Connect Conference and Expo. Attendees represented a broad range of organizations: academia, research labs, corporations, non-profit entities, and municipal government. More than 450 local, county and state government representatives and 250 participants from academia participated in the 2017 Application Summit. Collaboration between and among Summit participants is an important goal. To facilitate cross-sector connections and collaborations, 1,200 participants registered to use a conference networking/collaboration app and used the app to set-up more than 900 meetings during the Summit. By establishing relationships with researchers/developers and communities, US Ignite has begun to break the barriers between the technology and those who could use it to solve societal issues.
